title: Neurogenic Orthostatic Hypotension
scope: ** Evaluation and management of neurogenic orthostatic hypotension (nOH) in adults. Includes differentiation from non-neurogenic OH, etiologic workup (alpha-synucleinopathies, diabetic autonomic neuropathy, amyloid neuropathy, autoimmune autonomic ganglionopathy, pure autonomic failure), autonomic testing, pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic management, supine hypertension management, and falls prevention. Covers ED, hospital, and outpatient settings. Excludes non-neurogenic causes of OH (dehydration, hemorrhage, medication-induced) unless as differential.

Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Thyroid dysfunction contributing to autonomic symptoms
B12 deficiency neuropathy with autonomic component
Adrenal insufficiency as cause of orthostatic hypotension

Core Labs (All Patients).item: Orthostatic vital signs (lying → standing at 1 and 3 min)
Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Confirm OH; assess HR response to differentiate nOH vs non-neurogenic
Core Labs (All Patients).target: SBP drop <20, DBP drop <10; HR rise ≥15 bpm

Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Exclude cardiac arrhythmia or structural cause

Extended Labs (Based on Clinical Suspici.rationale: Differentiates preganglionic vs postganglionic autonomic failure; PAF shows low supine NE without standing rise
Extended Labs (Based on Clinical Suspici.target: Supine NE >200 pg/mL with ≥2× rise on standing

Rare/Specialized Labs.item: Fat pad or tissue biopsy with Congo red staining
Skin punch biopsy (epidermal nerve fiber density)
Rare/Specialized Labs.rationale: Small fiber neuropathy with autonomic involvement
If autoimmune or inflammatory etiology suspected

Essential Autonomic Testing.target: No sustained SBP drop ≥20 or DBP drop ≥10 within 3 min
Quantify BP and HR response to passive tilt; confirm nOH
Essential Autonomic Testing.contraindications: Severe aortic stenosis, critical carotid stenosis

Essential Autonomic Testing.item: Valsalva maneuver with beat-to-beat BP monitoring (CPT 95922)
Essential Autonomic Testing.target: Normal 4-phase response; absent phase IV overshoot in nOH

Essential Autonomic Testing.item: Cardiovagal testing — deep breathing, Valsalva ratio (CPT 95921)
Essential Autonomic Testing.target: Normal HR variability with deep breathing

Extended Autonomic and Diagnostic Studie.item: QSART — quantitative sudomotor axon reflex test (CPT 95923)
Extended Autonomic and Diagnostic Studie.target: Normal sweat volumes at standard sites
Normal sweat distribution; identifies pattern of postganglionic vs preganglionic sudomotor failure
Normal myocardial uptake; decreased uptake in postganglionic lesions (PD, PAF, DLB) vs preserved in MSA
Evaluate for peripheral neuropathy causing autonomic dysfunction
Evaluate for MSA (hot cross bun sign, cerebellar/pontine atrophy), PD, DLB

Rare/Specialized Studies.target: Differentiates PD/DLB (abnormal) from MSA (often abnormal) or non-synucleinopathy
Characterize circadian BP pattern; identify nocturnal hypertension, post-prandial hypotension
Normal; or identify restrictive cardiomyopathy pattern

Acute/Emergent Management.indication: Acute symptomatic nOH with hemodynamic compromise

dosing.instructions: NS 500-1000 mL bolus; repeat if needed based on response

Acute/Emergent Management.item: Medication review and discontinuation of offending agents
Acute/Emergent Management.indication: All patients with new or worsening OH

doseOptions.orderSentence: Medication review and discontinuation of offending agents N/A -

dosing.instructions: Review and reduce/discontinue diuretics, alpha-blockers, vasodilators, tricyclics, dopamine agonists
dosing.orderSentence: Medication review and discontinuation of offending agents N/A -

doseOptions.orderSentence: Supine positioning with legs elevated N/A -

dosing.instructions: Trendelenburg or leg elevation to improve venous return
dosing.orderSentence: Supine positioning with legs elevated N/A -

Acute/Emergent Management.indication: Acute symptomatic OH; pressor effect within 5-15 min

doseOptions.orderSentence: Bolus water drinking 480 mL (16 oz) PO

dosing.instructions: Rapid ingestion of 480 mL cold water; raises SBP 20-30 mmHg within 5-15 min via osmopressor reflex
dosing.orderSentence: Bolus water drinking 480 mL (16 oz) PO

doseOptions.orderSentence: Increased dietary salt intake 6-10 g/day PO

dosing.instructions: 6-10 g sodium per day via dietary supplementation or salt tablets (1 g tabs, 2-3 TID with meals)
dosing.orderSentence: Increased dietary salt intake 6-10 g/day PO

Non-Pharmacologic Therapies.contraindications: Heart failure, severe supine HTN, renal failure

dosing.instructions: Target 2-3 L fluid per day; distribute throughout the day
Abdominal binder (20-40 mmHg); more effective than leg stockings alone
Waist-high compression stockings 30-40 mmHg; thigh-high less effective

Non-Pharmacologic Therapies.indication: Supine hypertension mitigation; reduce nocturnal diuresis

dosing.instructions: Elevate head of bed 10-20 degrees (6-9 inch blocks under head posts); reduces nocturnal natriuresis and expands daytime plasma volume

Non-Pharmacologic Therapies.indication: Acute or chronic nOH; during prodromal symptoms

dosing.instructions: Leg crossing with muscle tensing, squatting, bending forward; raises BP 20-30 mmHg acutely

Non-Pharmacologic Therapies.item: Small frequent meals; reduce carbohydrate load

doseOptions.orderSentence: Small frequent meals; reduce carbohydrate load N/A PO

dosing.instructions: 5-6 small meals per day; limit carbohydrate intake per meal; avoid alcohol
dosing.orderSentence: Small frequent meals; reduce carbohydrate load N/A PO

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: nOH with persistent symptoms despite non-pharmacologic measures

dosing.instructions: Start 2.5 mg TID; titrate by 2.5 mg q1-2 weeks; max 10 mg TID; last dose no later than 4 PM to avoid supine HTN; onset 30-45 min, duration 3-4 hr

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Supine hypertension (SBP >180), urinary retention, pheochromocytoma, severe organic heart disease, thyrotoxicosis
First-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Supine BP (especially at night), urinary retention, scalp tingling, piloerection

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: Symptomatic nOH specifically due to autonomic failure (PD, MSA, PAF, dopamine beta-hydroxylase deficiency)

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg TID; titrate by 100 mg TID q24-48 hr; max 600 mg TID; FDA-approved for symptomatic nOH

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: Supine BP (measure before next dose and at bedtime); must re-evaluate efficacy after 2 weeks per FDA requirement

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.indication: nOH with volume depletion component; plasma volume expansion

dosing.instructions: Start 0.05-0.1 mg daily; titrate q1-2 weeks; max 0.2 mg daily; monitor for hypokalemia and supine HTN; off-label for nOH

First-Line Pharmacotherapy.contraindications: Heart failure, severe supine HTN, hypokalemia
First-Line Pharmacotherapy.monitoring: K+, Mg2+, supine BP, weight, edema

Second-Line/Refractory Therapies.indication: Mild-moderate nOH; augments ganglionic neurotransmission; less supine HTN risk

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg TID; may increase to 60 mg TID; best for mild OH; may combine with midodrine 5 mg for added benefit

Second-Line/Refractory Therapies.monitoring: Cholinergic side effects (GI cramping, diarrhea), HR

Second-Line/Refractory Therapies.indication: nOH refractory to first-line; norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor; benefits central autonomic lesions (MSA)

dosing.instructions: Start 10-18 mg daily or BID; enhances residual sympathetic tone; evidence from small trials

Second-Line/Refractory Therapies.indication: Refractory nOH; alpha-2 adrenergic antagonist; enhances norepinephrine release

dosing.instructions: Start 2 mg TID; increase to 5.4 mg TID; limited evidence

Second-Line/Refractory Therapies.indication: nOH with concurrent anemia (Hgb <11); expands red cell mass and blood volume

dosing.instructions: 25-50 units/kg SC 3x/week; target Hgb 11-12 g/dL; slow response over weeks

Second-Line/Refractory Therapies.contraindications: Uncontrolled HTN, thrombotic risk, pure red cell aplasia history
Second-Line/Refractory Therapies.monitoring: Hgb, Hct, iron studies, BP, thrombotic events

dosing.instructions: 12.5-50 mcg SC 30 min before meals; reduces splanchnic blood pooling

Second-Line/Refractory Therapies.monitoring: Blood glucose, GI symptoms, gallbladder US q6-12 months

Second-Line/Refractory Therapies.indication: Nocturnal polyuria contributing to morning OH; reduces nighttime urine output

dosing.instructions: 0.1-0.2 mg PO at bedtime (or 10-20 mcg intranasal); must hold fluids after dosing to avoid hyponatremia

Second-Line/Refractory Therapies.monitoring: Serum Na+ (check within 1 week of initiation and regularly), weight

Second-Line/Refractory Therapies.indication: Post-prandial hypotension refractory to meal modifications

dosing.instructions: 50-100 mg with first bite of carbohydrate-containing meals; reduces post-prandial glucose spike and splanchnic vasodilation

Second-Line/Refractory Therapies.contraindications: Inflammatory bowel disease, bowel obstruction, cirrhosis

Supine Hypertension Management.indication: Supine HTN (SBP ≥150 mmHg at bedtime); removed upon waking

dosing.instructions: Apply 0.1-0.2 mg/hr patch at bedtime; remove in the morning before rising; short-acting to minimize morning orthostatic worsening

Supine Hypertension Management.contraindications: Severe aortic stenosis, concurrent PDE-5 inhibitors, hypovolemia
Supine Hypertension Management.monitoring: Supine BP at bedtime and morning standing BP

Supine Hypertension Management.indication: Supine HTN at bedtime; ARB with moderate duration

dosing.instructions: 25-50 mg at bedtime only; assess morning standing BP to ensure no worsening of OH

Supine Hypertension Management.contraindications: Hyperkalemia, bilateral renal artery stenosis, pregnancy

Supine Hypertension Management.indication: Supine HTN at bedtime; direct vasodilator

dosing.instructions: 10-25 mg at bedtime; short-acting; useful for isolated nocturnal HTN

Supine Hypertension Management.monitoring: HR, BP, lupus-like symptoms with chronic use

Supine Hypertension Management.indication: Supine HTN at bedtime; vasodilatory effect

dosing.instructions: 25 mg at bedtime; reduces supine BP without excessive morning orthostatic worsening; off-label use

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Rise slowly from lying to sitting to standing; sit on edge of bed 1-2 minutes before standing
Patient/Family Instructions.rationale: Prevents rapid BP drop and reduces fall risk

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Recognize warning symptoms (lightheadedness, visual graying, neck/shoulder pain "coat hanger" distribution) and sit or lie down immediately
Patient/Family Instructions.rationale: Early symptom recognition prevents syncope and injury

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Perform counter-pressure maneuvers (leg crossing, squatting, bending) when symptomatic
Patient/Family Instructions.rationale: Raises BP 20-30 mmHg acutely; non-pharmacologic first-line

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Avoid large carbohydrate-heavy meals; eat small frequent meals
Avoid prolonged standing, hot environments, hot baths/showers, and alcohol
Patient/Family Instructions.rationale: All worsen venous pooling and orthostatic BP drop

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Maintain adequate fluid intake (2-3 L/day) and salt intake (per physician guidance)
Patient/Family Instructions.rationale: Plasma volume expansion is foundation of nOH management

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Drink 480 mL (16 oz) of water rapidly when symptomatic (osmopressor effect)
Report all falls, near-falls, and new symptoms to care team
Patient/Family Instructions.rationale: Falls are primary source of morbidity in nOH; guides treatment titration

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Avoid offending medications when possible (alpha-blockers, diuretics, long-acting antihypertensives, tricyclics, dopamine agonists at high doses)
Lifestyle & Prevention.rationale: Medication-related orthostatic worsening is the most modifiable risk factor

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Elevate head of bed 10-20 degrees nightly
Lifestyle & Prevention.rationale: Reduces nocturnal supine hypertension and natriuresis; improves morning orthostatic tolerance

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Home fall safety assessment (remove trip hazards, install grab bars, adequate lighting)
Lifestyle & Prevention.rationale: nOH patients have 2-3x increased fall risk; home modifications are evidence-based prevention

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Wear waist-high compression garments during the day; remove at bedtime
Lifestyle & Prevention.rationale: Reduces venous pooling; must remove at night to avoid worsening supine HTN
Valsalva maneuvers can precipitate syncope in autonomic failure

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Driving restrictions: counsel per local regulations until symptoms stabilized
Lifestyle & Prevention.rationale: Syncope or near-syncope while driving is a safety risk; individualized per severity

differential.features: Preserved HR response (≥15 bpm rise); identifiable cause (dehydration, hemorrhage, diuretics); resolves with volume or medication change
differential.tests: Orthostatic vitals with HR assessment; clinical history; medication review

differential.features: Triggered by emotional stress, pain, prolonged standing; prodromal nausea/warmth; bradycardia during episode; typically younger patients
differential.tests: Tilt table test (vasodepressor or cardioinhibitory pattern); clinical history

differential.features: Sudden onset without prodrome; exertional; palpitations; abnormal ECG; structural heart disease
differential.tests: ECG, telemetry, echo, Holter, EP study

differential.features: HR rise ≥30 bpm (or HR ≥120) on standing without significant BP drop; predominantly young females; lightheadedness, palpitations
differential.tests: Tilt table test or active stand showing HR criteria without OH

differential.features: Cerebellar ataxia or parkinsonism + severe autonomic failure; poor levodopa response; early prominent OH; hot cross bun sign on MRI
differential.tests: MRI brain, autonomic testing, cardiac MIBG (preserved uptake)

differential.features: Motor symptoms preceding or accompanying OH; levodopa responsive; tremor predominant
differential.tests: Clinical exam, DaTscan, cardiac MIBG (decreased uptake)

differential.features: Cognitive fluctuations, visual hallucinations, parkinsonism, REM sleep behavior disorder + OH
Known diabetes with poor glycemic control; concurrent peripheral neuropathy; gradual onset
Length-dependent neuropathy with autonomic features; cardiac involvement; weight loss; proteinuria
differential.tests: SPEP/UFLC, fat pad biopsy, TTR gene testing, cardiac imaging

differential.features: Subacute onset; diffuse autonomic failure (OH, GI dysmotility, sicca, pupil abnormalities); may follow infection
Fatigue, weight loss, hyperpigmentation, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia
Occurs after immobilization; preserved autonomic reflexes; improves with reconditioning

evidence.recommendation: Consensus diagnostic criteria for OH (SBP drop ≥20 or DBP drop ≥10 within 3 min)
Droxidopa for symptomatic nOH in autonomic failure (FDA-approved; short-term efficacy)
Midodrine for orthostatic hypotension (FDA-approved; raises standing BP)
Comprehensive review of nOH pathophysiology and management in alpha-synucleinopathies
Management of supine hypertension in autonomic failure: a balancing act
AAN Practice Parameter: treatment of nOH and supine hypertension
Autoimmune autonomic ganglionopathy: clinical features and response to immunotherapy
evidence.source: [Vernino et al. N Engl J Med 2000](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10995864/)

evidence.recommendation: Non-pharmacologic management of OH (compression garments, counter-pressure maneuvers, fluid/salt)
Cardiac MIBG differentiates Lewy body disorders from MSA
Pyridostigmine for nOH: augments ganglionic transmission with minimal supine HTN
Water drinking as pressor response in autonomic failure
Consensus definition of neurogenic supine hypertension in autonomic failure
Expert consensus on nOH screening, diagnosis, and treatment algorithm

monitoring.item: Orthostatic vital signs (supine, 1 min, 3 min standing)

monitoring.frequency: At baseline, 1 week after fludrocortisone initiation, then q3 months
At baseline, 1 week after DDAVP initiation, then monthly
monitoring.action: Hold DDAVP if Na <135; restrict fluids after DDAVP
Reassess treatment; PT referral; home safety evaluation

monitoring.item: Symptom burden (OH symptom scales — OHQ or similar)

monitoring.action: Reassess fludrocortisone dose; diuretic if HF develops

disposition.criteria: Mild OH responsive to fluids; no syncope or injury; known nOH on stable regimen with mild exacerbation; reliable outpatient follow-up arranged
Syncope with injury; recurrent falls; new diagnosis of severe nOH requiring inpatient workup; supine SBP >200 mmHg; significant cardiac arrhythmia on workup
Hemodynamic instability refractory to initial measures; syncope with significant traumatic injury; concurrent cardiac emergency
Confirmed or suspected nOH requiring formal autonomic testing; etiologic workup for alpha-synucleinopathy or amyloidosis; titration of nOH medications
New diagnosis nOH; monitoring for phenoconversion (PAF to PD/MSA/DLB); co-management of neurodegenerative disease
Stable nOH on medication; routine lab monitoring; medication reconciliation; BP management
